importQuicken.history.description: Set the maximum number of the recently used items at the top of the import/require list when no search words. Setting this to 0 will hide the recently used items.

importQuicken.javascript.indexFile.description: Insert "index" file name and also its extension to the path.

importQuicken.javascript.predefinedVaria.description: Replace the given file-name keys with its respective variable-name values. The file-name keys must be written in regular expression. For example, setting this to `{ "foo-(\\d)+": "bar_$1" }` writes `const bar_123 = require("./foo-123.js");`

importQuicken.javascript.variableNamingC.description: Define the variable naming convention. This has no effects on "importQuicken.javascript.predefinedVariableNames"

importQuicken.javascript.filteredFileLis.description: Filter the files shown in the list when adding an import/require statement. Both keys and values must be written in regular expression. For example, you are working on a file named "foo.js", and you want to see only the files ending with ".spec.js" in the list when adding an import statement, then you must set this to `{ "/foo\\.js$": "\\.spec\\.js$" }`. Note that the path separators will always be POSIX slash characters. The term `${TM_FILENAME_BASE}` in your right-side regular expression will be replaced with the active file name without its extension.

importQuicken.typescript.predefinedVaria.description: Replace the given file-name keys with its respective variable-name values. The file-name keys must be written in regular expression. For example, setting this to `{ "foo-(\\d)+": "bar_$1" }` writes `import bar_123 from "./foo-123.ts";`

importQuicken.typescript.variableNamingC.description: Define the variable naming convention. This has no effects on "importQuicken.typescript.predefinedVariableNames"

For example, you are working on a file named "foo.ts", and you want to see only the files ending with ".spec.ts" in the list when adding an import statement, then you must set this to `{ "/foo\\.ts$": "\\.spec\\.ts$" }`. The term `${TM_FILENAME_BASE}` in your right-side regular expression will be replaced with the active file name without its extension.

importQuicken.stylus.syntax.description: Insert either @import or @require. See also http://stylus-lang.com/docs/import.html

importQuicken.stylus.fileExtension.description: Insert STYL file extension to the path.

importQuicken.stylus.indexFile.description: Insert "index" file name and also its extension to the path.

importQuicken.stylus.quoteCharacter.description: Insert either single quotes or double quotes as a string enclosure.
